text: So when you are looking
to hire either from internal resource
or an external hire, what are some
of the things you're looking for
for either the SOC analyst role
or other roles within your organization?

Is there a particular
mindset you're looking
for or a particular skill set?
What is it?
- Within our organization,
there's 12 different job families.
And so a lot of people are like, "What?

You have an organization with
12 different job families?"

We sure do. Everything from
PMs, TPMs, support engineers,
systems engineers.
We have small tactical dev teams.

So we've got software
development engineers,
SDMs, security engineers.

Look, I'm listing everything
off like it goes on and on.
So, you know, across the board,

depending on the particular
job that you're going in,

there's going to be a
certain set of BQs, you know,

basic qualifications,
specific requirements.

However, when you talk about
working in our organization

as a whole, we're looking
for high judgment people.
We're looking for people who are used
to operating in ambiguous situations.

We're used to people who have
a natural disposition towards
being able to do the right thing.

And... I don't want to
say run into the fire,

I don't necessarily like
the way that looks right,
but, you know, maybe,
walk into it and assess it

before you go in and make sure
you enter it the right way.

So we're looking for those type
of people, those people who,

you know, are already
predisposed towards response
and want to have that higher calling
regardless of what position they're in.

- And I imagine a certain
level of curiosity
and how can I break things?
So make sure they don't break again.
- Oh, 100% and also people who don't like
to do the same thing over and over again.
Right?
Because even though that's part of

what happens when you run a
24/7 global operation center,
you're going to have monotony.
I want the people who are tired of it.
I want the people who are like, "Man,
you've been doing this for six weeks?"
Like, "I don't want to do this anymore."

And then they come up with
ways to get out of that,
or more innovative ways to fix it.
Or they, you know, automated solutions

or, "Hey, hey, maybe we try
this process a different way."
Those are the people I'm looking for.
The ones that want to question, you know,
why are we doing this this way?

And if it makes sense,
then they're on board.

And if it doesn't make sense,
then they work with others
to find a way not to do it anymore.
That's what I'm looking for.
- So you mentioned, you know,
it's a 24/7 shop, right?
That can be very stressful on a human

for quite some time.
- Oh my god.
- How do you look at things from a human
management perspective to make sure

that your folks are
not getting burned out?

That they do have that
ability to rotate through one
or more of those 12 job families

and, you know, have a fulfilling
career without just being
burned out every day at work?

- A lot of us in my
leadership team, you know,
have come from different careers

where we had career development
as a critical cornerstone to
how those careers function.

We didn't have that
initially when I took over
years ago in this space.

But it was something that I
felt important to incorporate

to make sure that people
saw a path forward,
not just level based.
It's not about getting to the next level,

but skills development, role
development, understanding

of the business,
conversations like that are

how we ended up moving
from just physical into
that fusion space of physical and cyber
and logical, right?

Is by saying how do we
develop these people
who are already really performing well?
How do we give them greater opportunities?
How do we pair with other teams?

How can we find more
opportunities to help and grow
and learn, right?

How do we actually hire and
develop the best, right?

That, "developed the best"
part that needed that focus.
So that's really where we dug in.

The threat landscape is constantly
changing faster than most
people out there can even think about.
So if we're only building security experts

who are only good in one
area, then there's no way

that we're going to be able
to keep up with, you know,

the fast changes that are
happening in the world.
So, you know, working with my leadership,
we start thinking about how can we make

what I call a full
spectrum security analyst.

How do we build a person
that is well versed in one
discipline and starts to build
and develop skills in another discipline?

And we start by taking over
smaller responsibilities.

We went through some
training, we worked with,
you know, different training programs,
sales courses, things of that nature.
And then we eventually decided that okay,
we would take on some of the stuff
that our other teams are doing
because we operate really well at scale.

And the good thing about the
SOC is, even though, you know,

we are backed by our people,
you know, our first tenant is

to, you know, always
automate for solutions first.
Humans are our last resort.
And in doing that, you know, we say, hey,

there are some workloads
though that even though

with the best intentions of
automation, you still need,
you know, a high judgment individual...
- For sure.
- ... to be able to take some actions.

So if you think about
it, it's kind of like

resource management.
- For sure.

- So through having that
discussion, we said, hey,

we can leverage some of those
things, building the capacity

of our people to be
able to operate across,
you know, the domains.
And then at the same time,

freeing up some resources from
our peers in the other side
of the organization so

that they could tackle
the more ambiguous tasks.

In terms of the actual
like day-to-day stuff,

like, you know, we absolutely
want to make sure that,

you know, little simple
things that we can do,
like have a snack bar available, right.

You know, like you'd
be surprised that a lot
of people worked in op centers

before is like, it really,
really is tough when, you know-

- Pizza goes a long way.
- Pizza goes a long way.

Pizza, you know, a couple of
drinks, some chips. - Right.
- Like, people are happy, you know?
And I'm not saying that to be, you know,
silly, but I mean...

- Oh for sure. It's a real thing.
- ...It's a real thing.
Like, you know, you're on that op center
and sometimes you're
so deep into what's going on,
you look up and you've been handling a
problem for four hours straight.
You didn't even notice that. Right?
And you need to be able to have some fuel,
you know, to keep you going.
We also, you know, make sure

that people have an
opportunity, like I said,

to rotate roles so they
know that, you know, "Hey,

here are the requirements to
move into a different role."
We do still have a on call, right?
On call, again, is unavoidable when you're
running a global system.

But in a lot of places
we've been able to move to

where we have that globalized
system where, you know,
we do a handoff, another team picks
up, and then we keep rolling.
- In preparation for this interview,
I looked at your internal teamâ€™s Wiki.
And you have your tenants published

there and, you know, tenants,
we use throughout AWS

to help people have guidance
when there isn't something

prescriptive down for
every particular situation.
Right? So it's how you operate.
And you mentioned one earlier, scaling
through humans is the last resort, which

of course you want to
really focus on automation

where it makes sense and
then the human can make those
risk-based decisions.

There's a couple more that
I'd love for you to speak to.
because I think they're fantastic.
- For sure.
- The first one: We don't punt, we pass.

- That's right.
- Tell me about that.

- Look, too many times
have we seen people get,
you know, busy.
A lot of things are going on.

And the first thing that
someone says, normally junior in
their career, "That's not my job."

We don't say that to customers,
internal or external. Right?

If we are not the ones
who own it, then we go

and we help you find the
right person who owns it.
And we give a soft, warm handoff.
We don't just say, "Hey, it's not us."
And then just punt it away.
Right? And that's internal as well.
If you call and you're looking for team A
and you call team C, team C doesn't tell

you it's team A.
- Right.

- Team C walks it over to
team A, makes it, "Hey,
team A, do you have it? You're good."

I've been on the receiving
end of it before and

after the second or third
time that you get transferred,

you're just like, "What's
up with this organization?"
- Aren't they the same company?
How are they not talking to each other?

- How are they not talking
to each other? Exactly.
So that's exactly why we did that.
- I love that.

And then the other one,
which may take a little bit

of explaining: Security
is not a secret society.
What is that about?
- I think, you know, a lot of people
who don't have a cyber background

or didn't work in highly
technological fields, they think
that it's so intimidating.

They're like, "Oh my
God, I can't learn that."
Or, you know, "I can't code."

I'm like, shoot, most of the
people I know can't code.
Like, I know a lot of people

who could code circles
around us too, right?
There's both types.

But you need all types in
the cybersecurity industry,
as we all well know.

If you put two military
people together, you know,
especially if they're the same service

and about five minutes
in that conversation,
they're speaking a different language.
Because of the acronyms that are flying
and the bases that you've never heard of,

the different words for TDYs
and deployment of this stuff.

Right? So the same thing happens
in the cybersecurity space.
So you have people coming on
and they're using all these code names
and they're using these acronyms.
And like, if you ask what it stands for,

it makes perfect sense.
- Sure.
- But if you don't know,

and you're just listening,
it just sounds like R2-D2
alphabet soup, right?
And it's so intimidating

that people are like,
"Oh, I can't do that."

And that's actually nothing
could be further from the truth.

So we seek to demystify
to say, you know what?
Let's actually, you know,
create an environment where we can learn.
Let's create an environment where
there's no environment of fear.

Ask the question. I
demonstrate this in meetings.

Like if you say an acronym,
I've never heard it
before, I'm going to ask you...

- What does that mean?
- I'm not embarrassed.
What does that mean? What is it? Right?
Like now I know.

And now I can tell
someone, you'd be surprised
how many times I've asked and a person has
said, "Oh, I don't know."
Okay?
- Everybody uses it.
- Yeah. Everyone gets used to the acronym.
So things like that, right?

And then I think the other
part of it is by being able

to be more, not just
precise with our language,
but also understanding of what

and how we're using our,
our terms and our words,

it creates an environment
where more people feel welcome
and able to contribute.
And the benefit of that,

and really, I really
mean this, the benefit of

that is there's someone in
that room who knows the answer

or there's someone in
the room that's thought
of something we haven't thought of.
And if the only thing holding them back
is they're afraid that,
you know, they might be embarrassed
or we might look at them funny
because they don't know anything.

I want to throw that out the
way, I want them to speak up.
I want to know what that is

because that might change the
way we do business completely.

- That would help AWS
and help AWS customers
and possibly more than that.
- Help the world.

- Help the world.
- Absolutely.
- Well, this has been fantastic, Tom.

I really appreciate your
time today. Thank you.
- Thank you so much for having me.
I really appreciate it as well.
